author: Emily Payne for MailOnline
title: How the super rich are taking over the world of online property rentals
text:
10 shares 2
View
comments
As property rental sites such as Airbnb continue to flourish, one particular demographic is benefiting immensely.
Once just the domain of cheap spare rooms in bustling cities, now the super rich are making a mint by renting out their second and third homes - even planning their own holidays around how they can accommodate guests throughout the year.
Replacing poky, thin-walled hovels are penthouse suites in Tokyo, apartments with rooftop swimming pools in Singapore and private islands private islands with nightly rates of £80,000.
Rental companies such as villas.com allow wealthy private owners to rent out property, like this £339 per night windmill villa, in Greece
According to recent reports, in June, the number of one bed listings charging more than £1,000 per night had increased threefold since the year before.
A spokesperson for Airbnb told MailOnline that there has been a growth of 163 per cent growth in one bedroom properties listed in London at over £1,000 per night.
Meanwhile, the growth in properties with luxury amenities, meaning gyms and swimming pools, has risen by 78 per cent in Tokyo, 70 per cent in Hong Kong, 53 per cent in London and 30 per cent in Paris, in the last year.

It's not only Airbnb users getting in on the act. Many other rental companies such as onefinestay.com, Villas.com and Luxury Retreats allow wealthy private owners to make some spare cash online by renting out their main or second homes online.
Villas.com specialises in self-catering vacation rentals – everything from chalets, cottages, apartments and gites to aparthotels, villas and condos. The property inventory hosts both individual owners and property management companies but the booking process is the same for both.
A private plunge pool and magnificent views: The Aqua Luxury Suites in Santorini would set you back between £108 - £445 per night
It has more than 318,200 holiday rentals around the world on its books, and of these rentals, 1,719 properties are priced at over £500 per night. 731 properties priced at over £750 per night.
Property rental sites make it hassle-free too. With the sites featuring calendars, so property owners can switch availability on or off, and messaging apps and review systems allowing them to vet potential guests before their stay.
After the price is decided, all the owner has to is decide whether to accept or reject potential visitors - some perhaps preferring to open their homes to a certain type of clientele. Often, party animals and families with young children need not apply.
Onefinestay.com even supplies linen and toiletries to each property, as well as cordoning off private areas which are off limits for guests.
Penthouse suites in London's Kensington can be rented out for as little as £187.71 per night to as much as £1150.58 per night
It also means that if you've got cash to burn, there is a far wider cross-section of property to holiday in. From private islands in the middle of a nature reserve in Brazil to Vauban fortresses for £450 per night and £1150 a night crash pads in Kensington.
And while, previously rich users were shy about posting pictures of their flamboyant homes - perhaps for fear of being judged by their neighbours, it's now seen as a great way to make some pocket money and join the sharing economy - something that has seen an unstoppable growth since it first surfaced in 2008.
Tastes of the super rich have changed since the financial crisis, with a shift towards sustainable living - making home stays a more popular choice than posh hotels. According to the Financial Times , there has also been an increase in business travellers, and staying in a home, rather than a hotel means business mean can feel like they have more of a home life balance.
And when that home is a luxurious penthouse with all mod-cons, who can complain?
